AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Eastern White Pine is an easily recognized tree with its soft, blue-green needles in bundles of five. It commonly grows to a height of 80 feet and more when undisturbed. The lumber industry in the United States was founded on the Eastern White Pine. Native Americans depended on the needles, buds, bark, comes, roots, and pitch for various uses. The tree was considered an important source of Vitamin C. The inner bark was said to have been used as an ingredient in cough remedies. It can been easily transplanted, grows best in fertile, moist , well-drained soils, but also has been found on dry, rocky ridges and in wet bogs. Air pollutants and salts are not tolerated by this tree. Eastern White Pines on the campus can be found on the corners of Main Street and Mark Street, and on Main Street and Howard Street. Look for them also around the parking lot on Huff Street and Sarnia Street.
thin, smooth, grayish green when young, becoming darker with age, dark grayish brown on old trunks and deeply furrowed longitudinally into broad scaly, 1-2" thick ridges
monoecious; staminate clustered, yellow; pistillate pink
cones, pendent 3-7" long by 1 1/2" broad, cylindrical, often curved, apex pointed, resinous and light brown; mature in autumn of second year; seeds are released in September
soft, pliable 2-5" long, bluish-green needles in bunches of five which remain on the tree two years, usually fall in late summer, early fall
one of the fastest growing landscape pines, needles are soft to the touch
sun, but can tolerate some shade

ThemeEntityData.Description: Eastern White Pine is an easily recognized tree with its soft, blue-green needles in bundles of five. It commonly grows to a height of 80 feet and more when undisturbed. The lumber industry in the United States was founded on the Eastern White Pine. Native Americans depended on the needles, buds, bark, comes, roots, and pitch for various uses. The tree was considered an important source of Vitamin C. The inner bark was said to have been used as an ingredient in cough remedies. It can been easily transplanted, grows best in fertile, moist , well-drained soils, but also has been found on dry, rocky ridges and in wet bogs. Air pollutants and salts are not tolerated by this tree. Eastern White Pines on the campus can be found on the corners of Main Street and Mark Street, and on Main Street and Howard Street. Look for them also around the parking lot on Huff Street and Sarnia Street.
